4.title: Case Study 4: Flawed vs Corrected Time-of-Day Weekly Sales Visualization
4.subtitle: Design ethics
4.description: Both charts show the same kebab-sales dataset. The first collapses seven days into averages and breaks encoding rules; the second keeps all 42 rows visible with a clean mapping.

flawed.label: Flawed chart
flawed.title: Misleading average pie
flawed.caption: A deliberately bad view that hides day-to-day swings behind averages and a mismatched pie layout.
flawed.chartDescription: Seven-day averages crammed into a pie with mismatched legend colors and no time ordering.

reasons.axis: Pie hides the y-axis entirely, so scale cannot be read at all.
reasons.colors: Overlapping warm colors make categories hard to tell apart.
reasons.legend: Legend colors are mismatched (evening and midday are swapped).
reasons.order: No consistent order for morning → evening, so the sequence is lost.
reasons.aggregation: Seven separate days are collapsed into averages so daily peaks and lows disappear.
reasons.mapping: Combines cities and times into one pie: the visual elements no longer match the data structure.

fixed.label: Fixed chart
fixed.title: Truthful panel lines
fixed.caption: Same data with honest scaling, distinct colors, and a calm layout. Every single row stays visible in one stacked SVG.
fixed.chartTitle: Daily kebab sales by city and time of day
fixed.chartDescription: Single SVG with three horizontal panels (Morning, Midday, Evening). Each panel has two lines (Berlin, Köln) over seven days, shared x-scale, independent y-scales.

reasons.baseline: Panels have y-axes and grids so scale is visible per time-of-day.
reasons.palette: Distinct, colorblind-friendly palette with clear contrast.
reasons.legend: Legend matches the encoding and separates the two cities clearly.
reasons.structure: Panels stack Morning → Evening vertically to keep time-of-day order obvious.
reasons.fullData: All 42 rows (2 cities × 7 days × 3 times) stay visible so trends and peaks stand out.
reasons.mapping: Single chart, shared day axis, independent y-scales per time band; two lines per panel keep city comparisons clear.
